- Source: PPC_Finger (human posterior parietal cortex recordings during attempted finger movements)

Data Source: Allen Brain Observatory — Visual Coding Neuropixels dataset (NWB, downloaded via AllenSDK). This dataset contains 58 experiments, each with up to 6 Neuropixels probes covering cortical, thalamic, and hippocampal regions, and is designed for systematic study of the mouse visual system under passive stimulation. This workflow uses drifting gratings (8 orientations) as an example, showing the complete process of session selection, unit filtering, spike matrix construction, time binning, and data saving. The official documentation describes the 8 orientations and temporal/spatial frequency settings in detail.
Generic Object Decoding (fMRI on ImageNet) - OpenNeuro
https://snel-repo.github.io/falcon/ DOI: 10.48324/dandi.000941/0.241029.1405 DANDI ID: 000941 / Version: 0.241029.1405 License: CC-BY-4.0 Access: Open Access
Species: Macaca mulatta (Rhesus monkey) Number of subjects: 3 (each dataset split counted as one “subject” in DANDI; actual recordings from one monkey for M1-A, additional monkey data here)

Type: Reach-to-grasp, center-out reaching task. Conditions: 4 different objects 8 possible target positions Behavioral events recorded: gocue_time move_onset_time contact_time reward_time result, number, tgt_loc, tgt_obj, obj_id, condition_id

Neural signals: Multiunit spiking activity from electrode arrays implanted in primary motor cortex (M1). EMG: Intramuscular EMG (iEMG) from 16 upper-limb muscles. Data format: Neurodata Without Borders (NWB).

Three data splits provided for the FALCON Challenge: held-in-calib: Many trials; intended for decoder calibration. held-in-minival: Small subset of held-in-calib; for validating model submission format. held-out-calib: Separate sessions with fewer trials; for few-shot recalibration.

preprocessed_emg: iEMG signals from 16 muscles. eval_mask: Boolean mask marking within-trial periods for benchmark evaluation. units: Spike times per recorded unit. trials: Trial-level metadata including timings, object/location IDs, and outcome.

Data Loading: Use pynwb or dandi Python client to read .nwb files. Signal Preprocessing: Align spike times, bin. Feature Extraction: Spike (mean firing rate, peri-event histograms). Label Generation: Map trials to discrete conditions; define time windows relative to events. Model Input Formatting: Spike matrices [trials, time_bins, units]

from dandi.dandiapi import DandiAPIClient import pynwb def load_falcon_dataset(nwb_path): io = pynwb.NWBHDF5IO(nwb_path, 'r') nwbfile = io.read() spikes = {unit: nwbfile.units['spike_times'][i] for i, unit in enumerate(nwbfile.units['id'][:])} trials = nwbfile.trials.to_dataframe() io.close() return spikes, trials
eval_mask is important for benchmark scoring. Dataset size ~297.3 MiB (11 files, created October 29, 2024).

This workflow processes 128-channel ECoG LFP data and converts it into a binned spike representation suitable for classification and pattern recognition tasks. The dataset contains: 128-channel LFP .mat files (one file per channel) Task_info.mat file containing trial labels and stimulus sequences Movie_start_time.mat file containing stimulus onset times Processing goals: Band-pass filter LFP (20–250 Hz) Segment into trials with uniform sample count Downsample to specified number of timesteps (target_timesteps) Extract spikes using an adaptive threshold Perform temporal binning to obtain a sparse spike array of shape (trials, binned_time, channels) Save as .npz file containing both spike and label fields

Parameter Purpose Variable Name Default Sampling rate Original LFP sampling rate (Hz) fs 1000 Channels Number of LFP channels n_channels 128 Trial length Duration of each trial (seconds) trial_duration_sec 4 Target timesteps Timesteps per trial after downsampling target_timesteps 50 Low cutoff freq Band-pass lower bound (Hz) lowcut 20 High cutoff freq Band-pass upper bound (Hz) highcut 250 Filter order Order of Butterworth filter order 3 Spike threshold Mean ± 2 × Std. Dev. auto-computed - Refractory period Minimum gap between spikes (ms) refractory_ms 2 Bin size Temporal bin size (timesteps after downsampling) bin_size 10

Load MovieSequence from Task_info.mat Build stimulus ID → emotion category mapping:{1: Fear, 2: Fear, 3: Threat, 4: Threat, 5: Neutral, 6: Neutral}Numerical labels: 0 = Frighten, 1 = Threaten, 2 = Neutral Load trial start times (ms) from Movie_start_time.mat Use the smaller length of the two arrays to ensure alignment

For each channel: Load LFP_ch{n}.mat Slice segments of trial_duration_sec starting from each trial’s start time Apply 3rd-order Butterworth band-pass filter (20–250 Hz) Downsample to target_timesteps using np.interp linear interpolation Shape transformation: Original: (samples,) After segmentation & processing: (channels, trials, target_timesteps)

For each trial and each channel: Compute mean μ and standard deviation σ Set detection thresholds:Positive threshold = μ + 2σNegative threshold = μ − 2σ Iterate over timesteps: If signal > positive threshold or < negative threshold → mark spike Enforce refractory_ms period where detection is skipped Output: spike_data shape: (trials, target_timesteps, channels) Values: 0/1

Group spikes into bins of size bin_size Count spikes within each bin Output shape: (trials, binned_time, channels) Example: If target_timesteps = 50, bin_size = 10 → binned_time = 50 // 10 = 5 Final shape: (n_trials, 5, 128)
Filtered LFP waveform plots Label distribution bar chart Spike raster plot Binned spike heatmap
Save to: processed/data_YYYYMMDD.npz Contents: spike: binned spike data (trials, binned_time, channels), dtype uint8 label: emotion labels (trials, 1), dtype int

Number of trials: 60, label shape: (60, 1) LFP processing complete, shape: (60, 50, 128) Spike detection complete, shape: (60, 50, 128) Binning complete, shape: (60, 5, 128) NPZ saved: .../processed/data_20100807.npz Fields: ['spike', 'label']

Filter cutoff frequencies: low cutoff > 0 Hz, high cutoff < Nyquist frequency Trial truncation: trials shorter than trial_duration_sec are discarded bin_size must evenly divide target_timesteps or the remainder is discarded Detection sensitivity: 2σ can be adjusted to 1.5σ or 3σ Refractory period: refractory_ms is measured in timesteps after downsampling, ensure proper conversion
Access the dataset here: 🔗 DANDI Archive - Dataset 000953

This project provides a complete preprocessing pipeline for the FALCON Benchmark M2 dataset, which contains neural recordings from the primary motor cortex in non-human primates during finger movement tasks. The goal is to transform raw .nwb spike train data into synchronized, windowed samples of neural activity and behavioral labels (e.g. hand position or velocity) suitable for training machine learning models.

Load spike times and continuous behavioral data (e.g. hand position, velocity) from .nwb files Convert trial-wise spike times into binary spike matrices Perform time binning to downsample spikes to match behavioral sampling rate Apply sliding windows to generate fixed-length training samples Save processed data as .npy arrays Optionally plot raster plots of example trials for quality inspection

Purpose: Downsample binary spike matrix by aggregating spike counts in fixed time bins. Inputs: spikes: numpy.ndarray, shape [time_steps, channels] bin_size: int, bin size in timesteps (e.g. 20 ms) Output: binned_spikes: numpy.ndarray, shape [num_bins, channels], spike counts per bin

Purpose: Slice time-aligned spike and behavior sequences into fixed-length sliding windows. Inputs: data: shape [num_trials, time, channels] label: shape [num_trials, time, behavior_dim] window_size: number of time steps per window stride: step size between windows Outputs: all_features_np: [num_samples, window_size, channels] all_labels_np: [num_samples, window_size, behavior_dim]

Purpose: Iterate over .nwb files Extract spike and behavioral data Bin spike data into 20 ms windows Apply sliding window slicing Save processed data Plot raster images for a few trials Parameters: data_root: directory containing raw .nwb files save_root: directory for saving output window_size: length of each training sample stride: step between samples
Place all .nwb files from the MonkeyN-held-in-calib session inside the data_root directory.

Example output structure: ../out/sub-MonkeyN-held-in-calib/ ├── 20201019Run1/ │ ├── spikes_20201019Run1.npy # spike features │ ├── reg_labels_20201019Run1.npy # behavioral labels │ ├── trial_0_raster.png # example trial raster

import numpy as np features = np.load('../out/sub-MonkeyN-held-in-calib/20201019Run1/spikes_20201019Run1.npy') labels = np.load('../out/sub-MonkeyN-held-in-calib/20201019Run1/reg_labels_20201019Run1.npy') print(features.shape, labels.shape)
After preprocessing and windowing, two arrays are generated:

Type: numpy.ndarray Shape: [num_samples, window_size, num_channels] Description: num_samples: number of sliding windows window_size: time steps per sample (e.g., 20 = 400ms) num_channels: number of spike channels (e.g., 64, 96) Each sample is a spike activity matrix input for a model.

Type: numpy.ndarray Shape: [num_samples, window_size, label_dim] Description: label_dim: 2 (e.g., hand (x, y)) or 4 (position + velocity) Each label corresponds to the spike sample, used for regression.

Default spike bin size is 20ms; you may change bin_size in bin_spikes_for_regression() Choose window_size and stride based on modeling requirements and dataset length Behavioral data sampling rate is 50 Hz; spike times are aligned accordingly Trials shorter than the window size will be skipped

Can't read .nwb files: Ensure files are complete and follow NWB v2.0+ spec Shape mismatch: Verify behavioral data aligns with binned spike data Need customization?: Reach out to the maintainer for help with modifications or enhancements

The Finger_RL dataset contains single-neuron recordings from two tetraplegic human participants attempting individual finger movements. Brain areas: Left posterior parietal cortex (PPC, PC-IP junction) Left motor cortex hand knob (MC) Data format: NWB (Neurodata Without Borders) Sampling rate: 30 kHz Number of subjects: 2 Task: Attempted individual finger movements (both hands) Data type: Single-neuron spike data, trial information, finger labels
Raw data: ../data/sub-P1/*.nwb Processed output: ../out/sub-P1/YYYYMMDD.npz features: [Trials, Time, Channels], with time dimension binned to 50 labels: finger class for each trial

Loop through all .nwb files. Extract key data from NWB files: units['spike_times']: spike times per channel intervals['trials']['start_time'] & stop_time: trial start and stop times trials['finger']: finger label for each trial Convert spike times to sample indices (multiply by FS). For each trial: Extract trial spike data based on start/stop indices Build a [time_steps, channels] matrix counting spikes per time step Perform time binning (default 50 bins) Stack all trials into [Trials, Time, Channels] Save as .npz containing features and labels

Function: bin_spikes_for_classify(spikes, expect_num_bins=50) Input: [time_steps, channels] spike matrix per trial Output: [expect_num_bins, channels] binned spike counts If trial length < total bin steps, pad zeros at the end
data = np.load('../out/sub-P1/20230409.npz') X = data['features'] # shape [Trials, 50, Channels] Y = data['labels'] # shape [Trials]

From .mat session files, extract spike counts (1 ms sampling) and behavioral signals (force/velocity/position, etc.): Downsample both to a fixed bin size (e.g., 20 ms); Segment data by trial and filter successful trials; Construct sliding window samples for regression/classification tasks; Export features and labels as .npz files for downstream model training.

Task paradigms: ISO (Isometric Force Control): Cursor on screen controlled by wrist force, 8 random outer targets; CO (Center-Out Reaching): Move planar manipulandum to 8 outer targets; RT (Random-target): Sequence of randomly presented targets; PG (Power/Key Grasp): Grasp force control task with 3 rectangular targets. Channels: 96 M1 channels, multi-unit threshold crossings; Spikes: spike_counts, counts per 1 ms bin (channel × time); Behavior: force/position/EMG, etc. (this example uses force → 2D).

Example archive: Jango_ISO_2015.7z → extract to obtain multiple .mat files. Key fields inside each .mat file (example xds group): trial_result: trial status code (82 = success); time_frame: timestamps in ms; spike_counts: channel × time spike counts (1 ms bins); force: 2 × time force signals (used as behavioral signal in this example); trial_start_time / trial_end_time: trial start/end time; trial_target_dir: trial target direction (degrees: -45). Note: Behavioral variable names may differ across tasks/monkeys. Map them according to README (e.g., position, velocity, or FSR force).

Enumerate .mat files → read xds/* fields using h5py; Filter successful trials (trial_result == 82); Slice spike counts and behavior by trial timestamps; Time-aligned downsampling (binning): Spikes: bin_spikes_for_regression(spikes, bin_size) → sum spikes per channel in each bin; Behavior: bin_behavior_for_regression(behavior, bin_size) → average value per bin; Normalize direction labels: map {0,45,90,135,180,-135,-90,-45} → {0..7}; Sliding window sample construction: create_windowed_dataset(data, label, trial_labels, window, stride): window (in bins) and stride control window length and step; Output: features [N, window, C], labels [N, window, F], trial_id/dir; Save: Each session/file → filename.npz containing features and labels.

Input: spikes [channels, time_steps], bin_size in ms (e.g., 20); Process: Divide time into expect_num_bins = time_steps // bin_size bins; discard remaining tail; sum spikes within each bin; Output: [expect_num_bins, channels] (time first). If input is [time, channel], transpose before calling.
Input: behavior [time_steps, features]; Process: Average within each bin; Output: [expect_num_bins, features].

Input: data: list of trials, each [T, C]; label: list of trials, each [T, F]; trial_labels: discrete label for each trial (e.g., one of 8 directions); window_size: length in bins; stride: step in bins. Output: features [N, window, C] labels [N, window, F] trial_meta [N] (trial label per window) Note: Discard trials shorter than window_size; use inclusive sliding windows (start=0..T-window step=stride).

Purpose: Batch-process .mat files, slice trials, bin, create windows, and save; Default params: bin_size=20 ms (~50 Hz); window=30 bins (~600 ms); step=6 bins (~120 ms) → 80% overlap; Output: .npz with same name as input, containing features and labels.

features: np.ndarray, shape [N, W, C] N: number of sliding windows; W: time steps per window (bins); C: number of channels; labels: np.ndarray, shape [N, W, F] F: number of behavioral features (example: 2 → force_x, force_y). For classification (e.g., 8 directions), derive window-level labels from trial_meta / trial_target_dir (e.g., center or majority vote). Current script saves regression labels (per-time-step behavior).
# 1) Extract Jango_ISO_2015.7z to ./Jango_ISO_2015 # 2) Run script (Python 3.9+) python main.py # internally calls nprmsce # 3) Generates <session>.npz

bin_size: 10–50 ms (match behavior bandwidth; 20 ms common); window: 300–1000 ms (task-dependent; CO/ISO ~500–800 ms); stride: 10–50% of window (controls sample correlation & dataset size); Behavior selection: ISO: force (2D); CO/RT: position/velocity (2D); PG: FSR force (1D or 2D difference/sum).

Mismatched shapes: spike_counts [C,T]; behavior should be [T,F] before binning; Tail discard: Binning discards remaining time < bin size → pad or use variable windows if needed; Trial indexing: Use indices[0]:indices[-1]+1 when slicing via time_frame; Task differences: Behavioral keys differ across tasks → handle in reading layer; Label mapping: Direction angles must map to {0..7}; skip or remap invalid angles; Data type: Use int16/float32 for large arrays to avoid overflow (int8 may overflow depending on spike counts).

Regression: Decode 2D force/velocity/position (R², RMSE metrics); Classification: 8-direction discrete intention (accuracy, F1); Cross-day alignment: Apply CycleGAN/ADAN/Procrustes for temporal robustness; Deep model input: Convert [N,W,C] to model-required format (e.g., [N,C,W] for CNN/RNN/Transformer).

Dataset: Ma et al., 2023, Dryad. Using adversarial networks to extend brain computer interface decoding accuracy over time. Hardware/Preprocessing: Blackrock Neurotech; threshold set at -4.75x ~ -6.25x RMS; 50 ms non-overlapping bins + 100 ms Gaussian smoothing (see README). This document provides practical data engineering and modeling instructions, not written in academic/IEEE style.

Source: PPC_Finger (human posterior parietal cortex recordings during attempted finger movements) Subject: Single tetraplegic human participant Task: BCI finger press task (cue on screen, participant presses corresponding finger) Recording Site: Left posterior parietal cortex (PPC, PC-IP junction) Electrode Array: 96-channel Utah array (Blackrock) Data Format: NWB (Neurodata Without Borders) Recorded Data: Sorted neural spike times (units/spike_times) Trial information (finger cue, cue location, start/stop times)

Convert raw NWB files into deep learning-ready input: Input (features): binned spike count matrix [Trials, Time, Channels] Output (labels): finger class [Trials] Save format: .npy files (per-trial spike and label)
Read all .nwb files in the data directory Use pynwb to open each file
Retrieve units['spike_times'] Convert spike timestamps to sample indices using FS Slice each trial to generate [trial_len, Channels] binned spike matrix
Retrieve trials['finger'] Store the finger class for each trial
Generate raster plots for first N_PLOT trials X-axis: time bins, Y-axis: channels Save as PNG files

Spike matrices → spikes_{date}.npy Finger labels → cly_labels_{date}.npy Example folder structure: out/sub-P1/ ├── 2022MMDD/ │ ├── spikes_2022MMDD.npy │ ├── cly_labels_2022MMDD.npy │ ├── trial_0_raster.png │ ├── trial_1_raster.png │ └── ...
Finger press classification Cross-trial decoding of intended finger movement Input for MLP / CNN / RNN / Transformer models

This project provides a kind of preprocessing Data from: Nonlinear decoding models enable music reconstruction from human auditory cortex activity dataset in the way that raw signals are transformed into signals for model training. The dataset contains intracranial electroencephalogram (ECoG) data recorded from 29 patients with drug-resistant epilepsy while passively listening to Pink Floyd songs. The dataset contains preprocessed neural activity (high-frequency activity, 70-150 Hz), electrode coordinates (MNI template space), and auditory stimuli (raw waveform files, and auditory spectrograms at 32 and 128 frequency points). The HFA and the two auditory spectrograms were sampled at 100 Hz and temporally aligned (190.72 seconds duration).

The original intracranial EEG data were read from the.mat format file. By defining the experimental starting point (positive and negative samples), a fixed-length time segment (200 sampling points) was intercepted according to each experiment, and the data feature matrix and the corresponding label file of each patient were saved.
Change the "raw_dataset_path" in process.py to the path of the dataset file, and specify the "preprocessed_dataset_path" variable to the path where the preprocessed data will be saved.
python process.py Running this file produces a preprocessed (.npy) file with the data stored in preprocessed_dataset_path.

import numpy as np data = np.load('./preprocessed_dataset_path/data_music_reconstruction_preprocessed.npz') features = data['spike'] #feature data of shape (number of samples, number of time steps, number of channels) label = data['label'] # Feature labels, of shape (number of samples, label), labels represent singing or musical events print(features.shape, label.shape)

This project provides A way to preprocess the Data for: A high-performance speech neuroprosthesis dataset to transform raw signals into signals for model training. The dataset consists of 12,100 sentences spoken by a single study participant. We use the "competitionData" version of it, which is a simplified version of the sentence data formatted and partitioned for machine learning research. It contains "train" and "test" partitions for model development, and a reserved "competitionHoldOut" set for the speech decoding competition (labels will be released after the competition). We currently only use the train (8800) versus test (880) partition data. For each sentence, a transcript of what the participant was trying to say was provided, along with a corresponding time series of neural spike activity recorded from 256 microelectrodes in speech related areas of the cortex.

The pulse signal data was read from the.mat format file for block standardization operation, and the corresponding sentence list and the corresponding time step number of each sentence were read. The neural signal data processed in the previous step are combined with their corresponding sentence transcriptions to generate a structured dataset for language decoding model training (e.g. converting brain signals into text). The key tasks include: alignment of neural signal features with phoneme sequences; Text cleaning, phoneme conversion, sequence normalization; Generate input formats for the model (fixed-length sequences, length statistics, etc.)

3.1 loadFeaturesAndNormalize()​ loadFeaturesAndNormalize(sessionPath) Purpose: Neural signal data are loaded and block normalized, and finally the processed features and corresponding text transcriptions are returned Inputs: sessionPath：str = ""，Path to the loaded subject file (.mat). outputs： session_data：dict{ 'inputFeatures': input_features, 'transcriptions': transcriptions, 'frameLens': frame_lens }, containing the following fields: inputFeatures：List[np.ndarray]， A normalized list of neural signal features with each element of shape (time_steps, channel). transcriptions：List[str]，The corresponding text list (with leading and trailing Spaces removed). frameLens：List[int]，Time step (number of frames) for each Trial. 3.2 getDataset()​ getDataset(sessionPath) Purpose： Data processing pipeline, which is used to convert neural signal data with corresponding text transcriptions into a format suitable for decoding model training. Inputs: sessionPath：str = ""，Contains neural signals and text data (.mat) file path. outputs: newDataset：dict{ 'sentenceDat': sentenceDat, 'transcriptions': transcriptions, 'phonemes': phonemes, 'timeSeriesLens': timeSeriesLens, 'phoneLens': phoneLens, 'phonePerTime': phonePerTime, }，containing the following fields: sentenceDat：List[np.ndarray]，list of neural signal features, each of shape (time_steps, channel). transcriptions：List[str]，The corresponding text list with leading and trailing whitespace removed. phonemes：List[np.ndarray]，Encoded phoneme sequence, fixed length 500, padded with zeros. timeSeriesLens：np.ndarray，The time step for each sentence. phoneLens：np.ndarray， The actual phoneme length of each sentence (without padding). phonePerTime：np.ndarray， The ratio of the number of phonemes to the length of the time series (for alignment).

Modify the path of "dataDir" in the process.py file to be the path of the "competitionData" file, and specify the value of "out_data" variable in the file to be the path where the preprocessed data will be saved.
python process.py Run this file to get the preprocessed (.npy) file.
├── out_data/ │ ├── data_SpeechBCI_preprocessed.npz # Preprocess the finished data

import numpy as np data = np.load('./out_data/data_SpeechBCI_preprocessed.npz') features = data['spike'] #feature data of shape (number of samples, number of channels, number of time steps) label = data['label'] #Feature label of shape (number of samples, label), label represents the encoded phoneme sequence, fixed length 500. features_len = data['X_len'] #time step of feature data of shape (number of samples) label_len = data['y_len'] #actual phoneme length (without padding) for each sentence in shape (number of samples) print(features.shape, label.shape, features_len.shape, label_len.shape)
LINK Dataset GitHub DOI: 10.1016/j.neuron.2021.08.009 DANDI ID: 001201 License: CC-BY-4.0 Access: Open Access
Species: Macaca mulatta (Rhesus monkey) Number of subjects: 1 (recordings from a single monkey; dataset spans multiple sessions over 3.5 years)

Self-paced finger movement task using two finger groups: index finger and middle-ring-small fingers Targets displayed on a screen: center-out style or random target style Each session: 375 trials Behavioral events: target onset, movement execution, target acquisition

Neural: Multiunit threshold crossings and spiking band power from 96-channel Utah microelectrode arrays in primary motor cortex (M1) Kinematics: Finger positions & velocities (normalized flexion/extension) Data standard: Neurodata Without Borders (NWB)

Total sessions: 312, recorded over 303 days (~3.5 years) Each NWB file contains: units: spike times SpikingBandPower: binned multiunit activity ThresholdCrossings: thresholded spike events index/mrs_position/velocity: kinematics trials: trial-level metadata

Load NWB files using pynwb Extract neural signals: threshold crossings, spiking band power Extract behavioral signals: finger positions and velocities Align signals with trial information: using trial start/stop times from trials table

Slice the continuous neural and behavioral data by trial For each trial, extract: Spike matrix: [time, channels] Kinematics matrix: [time, 2] (finger positions) Optional: convert spiking activity to firing rates using bins or smoothing

To prepare data for regression models: Apply a sliding window along the time dimension of each trial Window length: e.g., 100 time points; stride: e.g., 10 time points Each window contains both neural features (spike counts or SBP) and aligned kinematic labels Concatenate windows from all trials into a single dataset Save features and labels as .npz files for network input This allows the network to learn mapping from neural activity to continuous kinematics over short time segments.
Array Name Shape Description features [num_windows, window_size, n_channels] Neural input data labels [num_windows, window_size, 2] Finger kinematics (x, y)

Data Source: Allen Brain Observatory — Visual Coding Neuropixels dataset (NWB, downloaded via AllenSDK). This dataset contains 58 experiments, each with up to 6 Neuropixels probes covering cortical, thalamic, and hippocampal regions, and is designed for systematic study of the mouse visual system under passive stimulation. This workflow uses drifting gratings (8 orientations) as an example, showing the complete process of session selection, unit filtering, spike matrix construction, time binning, and data saving. The official documentation describes the 8 orientations and temporal/spatial frequency settings in detail. Original dataset link: https://portal.brain-map.org/circuits-behavior/visual-coding-neuropixels
Python ≥ 3.8 AllenSDK NumPy、tqdm、 pickle pip install allensdk numpy tqdm

By default, this workflow uses a local cache directory ./allen_vc_npx, where AllenSDK creates and maintains manifest.json and downloaded session/unit data. You can set a custom cache_dir in the parameters section.

Objective: From the Visual Coding – Neuropixels project, select sessions containing the drifting_gratings stimulus, filter units (neurons) within a specified brain region (e.g., VISp) that meet the SNR threshold, build raw 0/1 spike-time matrices for each trial, and perform time binning (standardizing to a fixed number of time steps). Finally, save the processed data as .npy: spike: integer spike count matrix with shape (num_trials, time_bins, num_units) label: integer vector (num_trials,), containing the class labels for the 8 orientations (0–315°, in 45° steps)

cache_dir = "./allen_vc_npx" : AllenSDK cache directory sampling_rate = 30000 ： Neuropixels native sampling rate (Hz) snr_thresh = 2.0 ： Minimum signal-to-noise ratio for unit selection target_area = "VISp" ： Target brain region (e.g., VISp) expect_num_bins = 50 ：Number of time bins per trial (for classification tasks)

Create/verify the cache directory and manifest.json. Load the project cache using EcephysProjectCache.from_warehouse(manifest=...). Read the session table with cache.get_session_table() and iterate over session IDs. AllenSDK’s EcephysProjectCache automatically manages downloads and local storage and is the recommended entry point for this dataset.
documents.s: Step 0: Initialize Project Cache and Session Table

documents.t: Copy session.stimulus_presentations and clean the orientation field (set "null" to NaN). Keep only rows where stimulus_name == "drifting_gratings", removing empty orientations. Keep the 8 valid orientations {0, 45, 90, 135, 180, 225, 270, 315}, mapping each to class labels 0..7. According to official documentation, drifting gratings use 8 orientations spaced 45° apart. Entries with null orientation represent blank screens and should be removed.
Select units from session.units where structure_acronym == target_area and snr >= snr_thresh.
documents.s: Step 2: Filter Units by Brain Region and Quality Metrics

documents.t: For each drifting_gratings trial: Compute trial duration from start_time to stop_time and convert to sample count (rounding up at 30 kHz). Initialize a (num_units_selected, num_samples) 0/1 matrix. For each unit, get spike_times[unit_id] within [start_time, stop_time), convert to relative sample indices, and set those positions to 1.
documents.s: Step 3: Construct Raw Binary Spike Matrices for Each Trial

documents.t: The function bin_spikes_for_classify(data, expect_num_bins=50): Accepts a matrix shaped [channels, time_steps]. Computes bin_size = ceil(time_steps / expect_num_bins). Pads with zeros if necessary to match bin_size * expect_num_bins. Reshapes to [channels, expect_num_bins, bin_size] and sums over the last axis. Returns [expect_num_bins, channels] . In the main loop, call this function for each trial and store results in X_list.
documents.s: Step 4: Perform Time Binning to Standardize Trial Length

documents.t: Stack all binned trials into X_array of shape (num_trials, time_bins, num_units) and convert label list to y_array. Save as .npy: data_dict = {"spike": X_array, "label": y_array} np.save("./allen_vc_npx/session_{ID}_dg8_{AREA}.npy", data_dict)

Place check_data.py in any directory. Modify the parameter section (cache dir, brain area, SNR threshold, bin count, etc.). Run: python data_process.py The script will iterate through sessions, process only those with drifting_gratings, and save .npy files in the cache directory.
session_{session_id}_dg8_{target_area}.npy: spike: integer (np.int8 or np.int32), shape (N, T, C) label: integer, values 0–7 for 8 orientations

Missing drifting_gratings: Not all sessions contain this stimulus; script skips missing ones. Consider supporting static_gratings or natural movie stimuli. Time steps & bin size: Larger expect_num_bins means higher temporal resolution but larger input tensors; adjust for model and memory constraints. Unit quality control: Current filter is SNR ≥ 2; you can add criteria such as firing_rate and ISI violations from AllenSDK.

This project aims to conduct standardized preprocessing on the BOLD5000 dataset, extract fMRI features and perform dimensionality transformation, providing high-quality input features and corresponding labels for subsequent model training related to visual cognition (such as image classification, brain activity prediction, etc.).

The time series data of all voxels in the ROIs provided in the dataset release 2.0 version (BOLD5000 Release 2.0) after GLM analysis are directly used as fMRI features (folder BOLD5000_GLMsingle_ROI_betas). This data has undergone the following process: [See the article BOLD5000 A public fMRI dataset of 5000 images] Preprocessing All the original fMRI data have been processed through the standardized pipeline using fMRIPREP 1.1.4, including: Motion correction, slice timing correction, geometric distortion correction Functional-anatomical registration, MNI152NLin2009cAsym spatial normalization Regression of 9 nuisance variables (6 motion parameters + CSF/WM/global signal) 128 s high-pass filtering Functional Localizer Analysis On 8 (or 6) localizer runs, use SPM12 to establish a GLM and run the following contrasts: Scene > Object & Scrambled →PPA, RSC, OPA Object > Scrambled → LOC Scrambled > Baseline → EarlyVis FWE correction (p < 0.0001, k ≥ 30) was applied to the significant voxels to obtain individual spatial binary ROI masks, which were then resampled to the MNI voxel grid. The time window was averaged (based on the peak activation of ROI signals). CSI1-3: average of TR3 + TR4 (4 - 8 s) CSI4: only TR3 (4 - 6 s) Signal extraction: the time series of all voxels within each ROI, demeaned. Main Experiment Single Trial GLM Modeling On the preprocessed main experimental data, a GLM-single-trial (LS-S) model was established for each stimulus image one by one: Each stimulus image corresponds to a regressor (stick function, 1 s ON, 9 s OFF). The same 9 nuisance regressors, run regressors, and 128 s high-pass filtering were again included. For each voxel within the ROI mask, the β coefficient (event-related amplitude) of this image at this voxel was solved.

The labels can be directly read from the event.csv file in the dataset. Each fMRI run has a corresponding events.tsv file, with fields including: onset: The time point when the image appears. duration: Usually 1 second (the time the image is presented). trial_type: Fixed as stimulus. stimulus: The file name of the image. ImgID: The unique ID of the image (used for pairing image features). ImgType: The type of the image (ImageNet, coco, scenes). The tag processing method is as follows: Extract the image type labels (ImgType) from the event.csv file and perform standardization processing. Standardization refers to classifying the rep category (repeated occurrences) and non-rep into one category. Convert the string format labels into numerical format acceptable by machine learning models.

Time Series Extraction Complete time series are extracted from each fMRI run and each active voxel, representing the distribution of BOLD signal intensity over time. As each run contains 37 visual stimuli (images), the length of the time series is 37. Time Series Segmentation The complete time series is segmented into three parts based on the dataset (COCO, ImageNet, SUN) to which the images presented in each trial belong, corresponding to the BOLD signals during the viewing of the three types of images. Preprocessing Linear interpolation is applied to the voxel-specific time series after segmentation to uniformly adjust them to the same time length, in order to meet the requirements of subsequent analysis. Conversion from 1D Time Series to 2D Spatial Features The 1D time series is transformed into a 2D matrix through Gramian Angular Field (GAF) to capture the spatial correlation features within the time series.

Gramian Angular Field (GAF): Through polar coordinate transformation, the normalized time series is mapped to a 2D matrix to generate Gramian Angular Summation Field (GASF) and Gramian Angular Difference Field (GADF), preserving time dependency without information loss. Specific Steps (1) Data Normalization Normalize a 1D time series (with length T) to the range [-1, 1]. The formula is: Run Python x_norm = 2 * (x - min(x)) / (max(x) - min(x)) - 1 Among them, x represents the original time series, and x_norm is the normalized result. (2) Polar Coordinate Transformation Map the normalized sequence to polar coordinates (r, θ): Angle θ: Calculated from x_norm as θ = arccos(x_norm) (since x_norm ∈ [-1, 1], θ ∈ [0, π]); Radius r: Normalized from the time step, r = t / T (t is the time index, t ∈ [0, T-1]). (3) Calculation of GASF and GADF GASF: GASF[i, j] = cos(θ_i + θ_j) GADF: GADF[i, j] = sin(θ_i - θ_j) Here, i and j are matrix indices, and θ_i and θ_j are the angles at the ith and jth time steps, respectively.

The main function of the mark_img function is to convert time series data into image data suitable for input into a convolutional neural network (CNN), as detailed below: def mark_img(dat): gram = GramianAngularField(image_size=16, method='summation')##change method='difference' for GramianAngularField difference gram_t = gram.fit_transform(dat.iloc[:,:-1]) x = gram_t.reshape(gram_t.shape[0], 16, 16, 1) y=dat['label'] return x,y

Core Tools for Converting Time Series to Images The GramianAngularField algorithm in the pyts.image library is used to convert time series data into images. This is a common technique for handling time series data, which can preserve the temporal correlation and amplitude information of the time series. Parameter Description GramianAngularField(image_size=16, method='summation'): Generates a 16x16 image, with the conversion method set to summation. It can also be changed to difference. dat: The input DataFrame, where the last column is the label (label), and the remaining columns are the time series feature data. Parameter 16 is specified for the article, mainly based on the experimental design corresponding to the dataset itself. Data Processing Steps Extract the time series features from the input data except for the last column (the label column) as dat.iloc[:,:-1]. Obtain the image data gram_t through Gramian Angular Field transformation, with a shape of (number of samples, 16, 16). Reshape the image data to the input format required by CNN, which is (number of samples, 16, 16, 1) (the last dimension represents the number of channels, and here it is a single-channel grayscale image). Extract the label column dat['label'] as the target variable y. Return Values x: The transformed image data (shape: (n_samples, 16, 16, 1)). y: The corresponding label data, used as the target value for model training. This function realizes the conversion from one-dimensional time series to two-dimensional images, preparing for the subsequent deep learning classification tasks.

Data is stored on a per-subject basis (supporting direct training with data from individual subjects). Usage method: Directly load the .npz format file through the np.load function. After loading, the corresponding data can be obtained through the two keywords fmri and label: fmri: fMRI two-dimensional image data, with a shape of (trials, height, weight), where both height and weight are 16. label: Label data, containing three values: 0, 1, and 2, which respectively correspond to: 0: coco category 1: imagenet category 2: scenes category The ratio of the three types of labels is 2:2:1.

The current data is based on the signals of all voxels within the ROIs (regions of interest) (refer to Article [1]). In practical analysis, in addition to using the signals of all voxels, it is also possible to consider performing dimensionality reduction on each ROI separately before conducting subsequent analysis.

V. K. Kancharala, D. Bhattacharya and N. Sinha, "Spatial Encoding of BOLD fMRI Time Series for Categorizing Static Images Across Visual Datasets: A Pilot Study on Human Vision," TENCON 2023 - 2023 IEEE Region 10 Conference (TENCON), Chiang Mai, Thailand, 2023, pp. 1117-1122, doi: 10.1109/TENCON58879.2023.10322476.
Access the dataset here: 🔗 Visual Grating Task | neurotycho.org

This project provides a complete preprocessing pipeline for Visual Grating Task ECoG recordings from neurotycho.org. The goal is to extract event-related segments from raw .mat files, perform preprocessing (e.g., common average referencing (CAR), downsampling), and save structured datasets suitable for neural decoding experiments. Reference: Neural Decoding Using Kernel-Based Functional Representation of ECoG Recordings

Load .mat ECoG recordings from multiple sessions in visual_grating_task/data/ Detect and extract specific events: blank and raster Apply CAR denoising to remove global noise Downsample high-frequency ECoG segments to a fixed length Save processed samples and metadata in .npz format Generate a processing report with detailed statistics
Purpose: Extract start and end indices for each labeled event segment (blank, raster) from the event label channel. Output: Dictionary containing event type, segment indices, and label values.

Purpose: Process a single .mat file, extract valid event segments, perform CAR denoising, and downsample. Outputs: Structured dictionary containing: samples: (num_samples, 300, 128) labels: (num_samples,) label_names: ['blank', 'raster'] file_info: (num_samples,), source file names sample_label_names: event names per sample
Place all .mat files from the Visual Grating Task dataset in: visual_grating_task/data/
Example output structure: visual_grating_task/data/ ├── visual garting task.npz # processed ECoG samples and metadata ├── processing_report1.txt # processing statistics

Type: numpy.ndarray (within .npz container) Fields: samples: [N, 300, 128] → N samples, 300 time points, 128 ECoG channels labels: [N] → integer class labels (0=blank, 1=raster) label_names: ['blank', 'raster'] file_info: [N] → source file names for each sample sample_label_names: [N] → human-readable labels per sample

Load Data Read .mat files with scipy.io.loadmat Access X matrix: X[:128, :] → 128-channel raw ECoG signal X[128, :] → event labels per time step Event Detection blank: label value in [300, 400] raster: label value > 100 and not in [300, 400] Extract continuous segments for each event type CAR Denoising car_signal = signal_data - np.mean(signal_data, axis=0, keepdims=True) Segment Selection Keep only segments with length ≥ 1920 samples Extract [start+20 : start+20+1900] to avoid state transition artifacts Downsampling Interpolate 1900 samples → 300 samples per channel Sample Assembly Shape each event to (300, 128) Store label, class name, and source file info
Label Value Event Name Condition 0 blank [300, 400] 1 raster >100 and not in [300, 400]
The generated processing_report1.txt contains: Total processed files Total number of valid samples Per-class sample counts Sample counts per original file

MAT file load errors: Check file integrity and MATLAB version compatibility No valid events found: Ensure event label channel exists and matches expected codes Unexpected shapes: Verify that all .mat files have the correct X matrix format

This project provides a way to preprocess the EEG Motor Movement/Imagery dataset by transforming raw EEG signals into signals for model training. Only two subsets of the EEG Motor Movement/Imagery dataset were used in the project. The first subset contains only performed left or right hand motor tasks. The second subset contains only imagined left or right hand motor tasks. In both subsets, a total of 103 out of 109 subjects were used, and subjects 38, 88, 89, 92, 100, and 104 were omitted due to data annotation errors.

The input data for each trial is split into (64, W) dimensions, where W represents the time dimension and 64 represents the number of channels. Because each trial of the execution and imagination tasks consisted of 4 to 4.1 seconds of continuous, sustained execution or imagination movement, all trials were truncated to contain exactly 4 seconds of data, sampled at 160 Hz, for a total of 640 samples to maintain a consistent dataset. Using the sliding window approach, the 640 samples in each trial were cut into eight non-overlapping Windows, each containing 80 samples. Each window was assigned the same target label as the original trial. Effectively increasing the size of the dataset by a factor of 8, providing more usable data. Using Gumpy BCI signal processing module in the library (https://www.mdpi.com/2073-431X/9/3/72#B21-computers-09-00072)] processing eeg signals. A notch filter was applied to the data to eliminate alternating current (AC) noise at 60 Hz frequency. The data were further band-pass filtered in the range of 2 Hz to 60 Hz with an order of 5.

3.1 load_data()​ load_data(nr_of_subj,trial_type,chunk_data,chunks,base_folder,processed_out_folder,sample_rate,samples,cpu_format,preprocessing,hp_freq,bp_low,bp_high,notch,hp_filter,bp_filter,artifact_removal) Purpose:Loads and preprocesses multi-subject electroencephalogram (EEG) data, supports band-pass/high-pass/notch filtering, artifact removal, and data slicing. Returns the preprocessed feature matrix and label array, and stores the preprocessed data in npz format (described in Section 4.4) in the folder specified by processed_out_folder. Inputs： nr_of_subj：int = 109，Number of loaded subjects. trial_type：int = 1，Trial type identification (e.g. ' Perform movement of type 1', ' imagine movement of type 2', ' perform movement and imagine movement of type 3') . chunk_data：bool = True，Whether to split each trial into multiple chunks. chunks：int = 8，Number of chunks per trial, only if' chunk_data=True '. chunk_data：bool = True，Whether to split each trial into multiple chunks. cpu_format：bool = True，Whether to format the output data into a Numpy array that can be processed by the CPU (possibly a GPU Tensor otherwise). preprocessing：bool = True，Whether to perform preprocessing (filtering, artifact removal, etc.). hp_freq：float= 0.5，High pass filter cutoff frequency (Hz), only works if 'hp_filter=True'. bp_low：float= 2.0，Bandpass filter low cutoff frequency (Hz), only works if 'bp_filter=True'. bp_high：float= 60.0，Bandpass filter high cutoff frequency (Hz), only works if 'bp_filter=True'. notch：bool = True，Whether or not notch filtering (used to remove power interference such as 50Hz/60Hz) is enabled. hp_filter：bool = False，Whether to perform high-pass filtering (overriding the' hp_freq 'setting). bp_filter：bool = True，Whether to perform bandpass filtering (override 'bp_low' and 'bp_high' Settings). artifact_removal：bool = True，Whether or not to do artifact removal. base_folder：str= ""， The folder name where the dataset is located. processed_out_folder：str= ""，The name of the folder where the preprocessed dataset is located. sample_rate：int= 160，The sample rate. samples：int= 640， Sample points. outputs： all_features：preprocessed EEG feature data, usually of shape '(number of samples, number of channels, number of points in time)'. all_labels：the label of the corresponding example (number of examples, label), whether the movement is left or right hand'.
Put the folder containing all the data in "base_folder".

python load_data( nr_of_subj=109, trial_type=1, chunk_data=True, chunks=8, base_folder= "./data/", processed_out_folder="./out_data/", sample_rate=160, samples=640, cpu_format=False, preprocessing= rue, hp_freq=0.5, bp_low=2.0, bp_high=60.0, notch=True, hp_filter=False, bp_filter=True, artifact_removal=True ) By setting the "trial_type" value, you can get three types of pre-processed data. In addition, you can get different data pre-processed results according to the parameters you set.

├── out_data/ │ ├── EMM_task1_preprocessed.npz # Perform motion type preprocessing of the data │ ├── EMM_task2_preprocessed.npz # Preprocessed data for types of imagined movements │ ├── EMM_task3_preprocessed.npz # Perform preprocessed data for movement and imagination movement

import numpy as np data = np.load('./out_data/EMM_task1_preprocessed.npz') features = data['eeg'] # feature data of shape (number of samples, number of channels, number of time points) labels = data['labels'] # Feature data labels of shape (number of samples, labels), where labels represent left or right hand motion print(features.shape, labels.shape)
Generic Object Decoding (fMRI on ImageNet) - OpenNeuro

Based on the requirements of the classification task, we only use the perceptionTraining subset (150 categories × 8 images = 1,200 natural images). This subset has undergone standard fMRI preprocessing in the original paper, including head motion correction, spatial registration, and global normalization, making it suitable for subsequent training-test splitting.
documents.s: I. Brief Description of the Dataset

documents.t: Input Preprocessed 4-D fMRI time series (func.nii.gz) located in the derivatives folder Predefined ROI masks (V1.nii.gz, LOC.nii.gz, FFA.nii.gz, PPA.nii.gz, etc., binary masks) Workflow import nibabel as nib, numpy as np img = nib.load('func.nii.gz').get_fdata() # (X,Y,Z,T) mask = nib.load('V1.nii.gz').get_fdata().astype(bool) roi_t = img[mask, :] # (N_voxel, T) Output 2D matrix for each ROI: roi_t (number of voxels × number of TRs).
documents.s: 1. ROI Signal Extraction (Based on Existing Data and Mask Files)

documents.t: Alignment Logic fMRI sampling period (TR) = 3 s; HRF peak lag ≈ 4–6 s. The signal of the corresponding TR after shifting the stimulus onset time backward by 1 TR (3 s) is taken as the stimulus sample. Label Table CSV format: onset, category_index A one-to-one mapping is established between onset times and TR indices.

Raw Data Format: fMRI data is stored in .nii.gz format, event markers in .tsv format, and ROI masks in .nii.gz format. Data Organization: Structured hierarchically by subject, session, and run. Key Parameters: TR (Repetition Time): 3.0 seconds Stimulus Duration: 9.0 seconds Number of TRs per trial: 3 (9.0/3.0)

Files of different types are matched using regular expressions: fMRI data files: (sub-\d+)_ses-(perceptionTraining\d+)_task-perception_run-(\d+)_bold_preproc\.nii\.gz Event marker files: (sub-\d+)_ses-(perceptionTraining\d+)_task-perception_run-(\d+)_events\.tsv ROI mask files: (sub-\d+)_mask_(.+)\.nii\.gz A data index dictionary is constructed to map subjects to their corresponding data files.

Load ROI masks for each subject and perform binarization. Count the number of voxels in each ROI and calculate the total number of voxels. Save ROI names and their corresponding voxel counts in a fixed order to ensure data consistency.

Load fMRI data (shape: [x, y, z, t]) and event files. Determine the TR index for each trial based on the onset time in the event file. Extract voxel signals of all ROIs for each trial: Concatenate voxel signals in ROI order. Form trial data with the shape [total voxels, TRs_per_trial]. Encode trial labels into zero-starting integer codes uniformly.

Standardize data using StandardScaler. Processing target: All trial data at each time point (TR). Standardization goal: Mean = 0, Standard deviation = 1. Shape change: [Trials, Total voxels] → [Trials, Total voxels]

Perform Principal Component Analysis using sklearn.decomposition.PCA. Core parameter: n_components (number of principal components, adjustable as needed). Dimensionality reduction strategy: Process each time point (TR) separately. Shape change: [Trials, Total voxels] → [Trials, Number of principal components]

Integrate dimensionality reduction results from all time points. Final feature matrix shape: (Number of samples × Number of principal components × Number of TRs). Retain PCA model parameters (component matrix and explained variance ratio).

Data is stored per subject. Load .npz files directly using the np.load function. After loading, the following keywords can be used to access corresponding data: fmri: fMRI data with shape (trials, number of principal components, TRs). label: Label data containing 150 values (0–149), each corresponding to a different category. Additional extended keywords: label_names: Obtain specific names corresponding to labels. rois: Obtain information about Regions of Interest (ROIs). roi_voxel_counts: Obtain the number of voxels in each ROI.

The n_components parameter can be adjusted according to actual needs to balance the dimensionality reduction effect and computational resource consumption. The data uploaded in this study has been reduced to 1000 dimensions, which is the setting that achieved the optimal classification performance in the current experiments. For data augmentation, category-specific processing was attempted, but experimental results showed that the adopted data augmentation methods did not improve the classification performance, so they were not included in the final workflow.

Participants: 15 subjects, each performing 3 sessions on different days. Trials: Each session contains 24 trials; in each trial, participants watch a film clip designed to evoke one of four emotions: happiness, sadness, fear, or neutral. Equipment: 62-channel ESI NeuroScan EEG system (for EEG signals) SMI eye-tracking glasses (for eye movement data)

EEG Signal Preprocessing​ Downsampling Resample the original EEG data to a uniform sampling rate of 200 Hz. Bandpass Filtering Apply a 1 Hz to 75 Hz bandpass filter to remove noise and artifacts. Feature Extraction Compute the power spectral density (PSD) and differential entropy (DE) over 5 frequency bands (delta, theta, alpha, beta, gamma) for non-overlapping 4-second segments. Feature Smoothing Reduce noise using moving average or linear dynamic system filtering methods.

Each trial is labeled with the emotion category of the corresponding film clip (happy, sad, fear, neutral). The time windows of the data are aligned with labels; each 4-second segment corresponds to one sample.

python复制编辑def load_data(session_id, sub_id): """ Load a .npz data file for a specific session and subject ID. :param session_id: int, optional, default=1 The session number, corresponding to the folder named "session{session_id}". :param sub_id: int, optional, default=1 The subject ID used to filter files starting with "{sub_id}_". :return: numpy.lib.npyio.NpzFile or None The loaded npz file object if found; otherwise None. """ for file in os.listdir(f"session{session_id}"): if file.startswith(f'{sub_id}_') and file.endswith('.npz'): print(f"Loading data from: {file} (session={session_id})") return np.load(os.path.join(f"session{session_id}", file), allow_pickle=True)

The .npz files contain two arrays named 'features' and 'labels', which store the sample features and labels, respectively. features is a 3D array representing multiple samples, with dimensions typically corresponding to samples × channels × frequency bands. labels is a 1D array containing the emotion label for each sample.

Number: 20 participants (10 male, 10 female), aged 19–26 years (mean: 22.5, STD: 1.8). Condition: All right-handed, with normal or corrected-to-normal vision and normal hearing. Selection: Screened using the Eysenck Personality Questionnaire (EPQ).

Each participant completed 4 sessions (on different days). Each session contained 20 trials: Part 1: Watching video clips for emotion induction (duration: 2–5 minutes). Part 2: Self-assessment of emotional state (score range: 0–1).

A total of 80 video clips: Emotions: Happiness, Sadness, Fear, Anger, Disgust, Surprise, Neutral (Neutral has only 8 clips). Each session contained only 5 out of the 7 emotions to avoid excessive emotional switching. The video sequence was carefully arranged to avoid sudden emotional changes.

Bad Channel Inspection & Interpolation Visually inspect EEG signals using MNE-Python, and interpolate any bad channels. Filtering Bandpass filter: 0.1–70 Hz Notch filter: 50 Hz (to remove powerline interference) Downsampling From the original 1000 Hz sampling rate to 200 Hz. Segmentation & Feature Extraction Window size: Non-overlapping 4-second segments Frequency bands: δ (1–4 Hz) θ (4–8 Hz) α (8–14 Hz) β (14–31 Hz) γ (31–50 Hz) Feature: Differential Entropy (DE) Feature Smoothing Apply Linear Dynamic System (LDS) smoothing or moving average.

Label source: Target emotion category of each video (7 classes) + subjective score (0–1). Time alignment: EEG/Eye-tracking features are aligned with the video playback timeline, with each 4-second window treated as one sample.

import os import numpy as np def load_data(session_id, sub_id): """ Load a .npz data file for a specific session and subject ID. Parameters ---------- session_id : int, optional, default=1 The session number, corresponding to the folder named "session{session_id}". sub_id : int, optional, default=1 The subject ID used to filter files starting with "subject{sub_id}". Returns ------- numpy.lib.npyio.NpzFile or None The loaded npz file object if found; otherwise None. """ for file in os.listdir(f"session{session_id}"): if file.startswith(f'subject{sub_id}') and file.endswith('.npz'): print(f"Loading data from: {file} (session={session_id})") return np.load(os.path.join(f"session{session_id}", file), allow_pickle=True)

features: 3D array [samples, frequency_bands, channels] Frequency bands fixed at 5 (δ, θ, α, β, γ) Channels fixed at 62 labels: 1D array [samples] Each element is an emotion category label (0–6 or 0–3, depending on task definition)

This project provides a preprocessing method for the THINGS-EEG dataset, transforming raw EEG signals into model-ready data. The dataset contains high-temporal-resolution EEG responses from 10 participants to naturalistic object images, recorded using a Rapid Serial Visual Presentation (RSVP) paradigm. Each participant completed 82,160 trials, covering 16,740 image conditions. The training set consists of 16,540 (image categories) × 10 (images per category) × 4 (repetitions), and the test set contains 200 (image categories) × 1 (image) × 80 (repetitions). Training and test stimuli were presented in a pseudo-random order, and target images were used to reduce blinking and other artifacts. EEG was recorded with a 64-channel EASYCAP (electrodes arranged according to the standard 10–10 system) and a BrainVision actiCHamp amplifier at 1000 Hz sampling rate, with online filtering (0.1–100 Hz) and referencing to the Fz electrode.

EEG data was segmented into trials from 0 to 1000 ms after stimulus onset. Baseline correction was applied using the 200 ms pre-stimulus period. All channels were downsampled to 250 Hz for analysis, and multivariate noise normalization (MVNN) was applied. The EEG responses for all repetitions were averaged to improve the signal-to-noise ratio, and the effect of the number of repetitions was also analyzed. Images were resized to 224×224 and normalized before being processed by an image encoder. The CLIP (Contrastive Language-Image Pretraining) model was used to extract pretrained image features.

3.1 epoching ()​ epoching(args, data_part, seed) Function: Converts raw EEG data to MNE format, performs channel selection, epoching, baseline correction, and downsampling. The EEG data is classified and sorted according to image conditions. Input Parameters: args: Namespace containing experimental configuration (e.g., sampling rate sfreq, subject number sub). data_part: str, data partition ('test' or 'training'). seed: int, random seed for reproducibility. Output: epoched_data: List[float], epoched EEG data sorted by image conditions. img_conditions: List[int], unique image condition labels. ch_names: List[str], EEG channel names. times: float, EEG time points (relative to stimulus onset). 3.2 mvnn()​ mvnn(args, epoched_test, epoched_train) Function: Computes the covariance matrix of EEG data (averaged over time points or trials), calculates the inverse square root (whitening matrix), and applies it to the test and training EEG data to remove channel correlations. Input Parameters: args: Namespace containing configuration parameters (e.g., mvnn_dim specifying covariance computation dimension). epoched_test: List[float], epoched EEG test data (shape: [conditions × repetitions × channels × time]). epoched_train: List[float], epoched EEG training data (shape: [conditions × repetitions × channels × time]). Output: whitened_test: List[float], whitened EEG test data (same shape as input). whitened_train: List[float], whitened EEG training data (same shape as input).
Place all files from the dataset's Raw EEG data and Image set folders into the directory specified by the project_dir variable in processing.py.

First, run processing.py to obtain preprocessed EEG data (in .npy format). The data will be saved to project_dir/Preprocessed_data_250Hz. python processing.py # Specify the subject (sub) and the dataset save directory (project_dir) Next, run obtain_feature_maps_clip.py to extract pretrained image features (in .npy format) using the CLIP model. The features will be saved to out_data. python obtain_feature_maps_clip.py Finally, run processed.py to generate the final preprocessed dataset files (in .npz format). You need to specify the paths to the preprocessed EEG data and image features (project_dir) as well as the output save path (out_data). python processed.py

├── out_data/ │ ├── sub01 │ │ ├── preprocessed_eeg_training.npz # Preprocessed EEG training data │ │ ├── preprocessed_eeg_test.npz # Preprocessed EEG test data │ │ ├── clip_feature_maps_training.npz # CLIP-pretrained image features for training set │ │ ├── clip_feature_maps_test.npz # CLIP-pretrained image features for test set │ ├── sub02

import numpy as np # Load EEG training data data = np.load('./out_data/sub01/preprocessed_eeg_training.npz') features = data['eeg'] # Shape: (samples, channels, time points) labels = data['labels'] # Shape: (samples,), labels represent image categories # Load image feature training data data = np.load('./out_data/sub01/clip_feature_maps_training.npz') features_image = data['image_feature'] # Shape: (samples, features) labels_image = data['labels'] # Shape: (samples,), labels represent image categories print(features.shape, labels.shape) print(features_image.shape, labels_image.shape)

Dataset Name: Long-term recordings of motor and premotor cortical spiking activity during reaching in monkeys DOI: 10.48324/dandi.000688/0.250122.1735 Authors: Perich, Matthew G.; Miller, Lee E.; Azabou, Mehdi; Dyer, Eva L. Data Types: Neural signals: Multi-channel recordings from M1 / PMd brain regions (192 channels), manually spike sorted or threshold crossings Behavioral signals: Cursor position, velocity, and task-related metadata Experimental Tasks: Center-Out (CO) task and continuous random target task Data Standard: NWB (Neurodata Without Borders) Sampling Rate: 1000 Hz

Process the raw NWB data into trial-based samples suitable for neural decoding or regression tasks, including: Segment spike data by trial; Resample each trial to a fixed number of time bins (BINNED_LEN = 50); Construct spike matrices [Time, Channel] for each trial; Convert each trial's target direction into 8 categorical labels; Save the processed data as .npz files with features and labels fields.

Parameter Description Example Value FS Neural data sampling rate 1000 Hz BINNED_LEN Number of time bins per trial after resampling 50 DATA_ROOT Path to raw NWB files ./data/sub-C/CO SAVE_ROOT Path to save processed data ./out/sub-C/CO
Only process .nwb files; Extract the file date YYYYMMDD for saving purposes.
with NWBHDF5IO(nwb_path, 'r') as io: f = io.read()

results: trial success indicator ('R' indicates successful trial) start_time / stop_time: trial start and end times target_dir: trial target direction Filter successful trials and convert target directions into 8 categories: tgt_dir_after = tgt_dir_after / np.pi * 4 tgt_dir_after = np.round(tgt_dir_after).astype(np.int32)
spike_times: spike timestamps for each channel (in seconds) Convert to sample indices: spikes_idx = np.round(spike_times * FS)
For each trial: Create a zero matrix [trial_len, n_channels]; Mark spike times with 1s; Resample evenly to [BINNED_LEN, n_channels].

documents.t: Create directory: SAVE_ROOT/YYYYMMDD Save as .npz file: np.savez(os.path.join(SAVE_ROOT, f'{date}.npz'), features=trials, labels=cly_trials) features: list of [BINNED_LEN, n_channels] matrices labels: categorical target direction for each trial [0, 7]
Spike raster plots ([time, channel]) Trial label distribution Heatmaps of binned spike activity

Only successful trials are retained (results == 'R'); BINNED_LEN can be adjusted according to model requirements; Spike indices should be rounded and bounded to avoid overflow; Target directions are converted to 8 integer categories for classification models.

This dataset is sourced from Zenodo Record 3854034, which contains invasive neural recordings from the primary motor cortex (M1) of non-human primates performing a center-out cursor control task. The neural data were recorded using a 192-channel Utah array, and the behavioral data consist of 2D cursor positions and corresponding target positions. Each .mat file corresponds to one recording session. The original dataset includes: Spikes: Sorted spike times for up to 3 units per channel. Cursor position: Continuous 2D coordinates. Target position: 2D coordinates indicating the current target location. Timestamps: Trial-aligned timing information.

Subjects: Non-human primates (NHP) implanted with a 192-channel Utah array. Task: Center-out cursor control with changing target positions. Neural signals: Spike times from up to three sorted units per electrode. Behavioral signals: Cursor position (cursor_pos) and target position (target_pos). Sampling rate: 250 Hz (behavioral sampling in raw files).
The preprocessing was conducted using preprocess.py, which transforms raw .mat files into binned, windowed datasets suitable for regression-based decoding models.
Extract spike times for all channels and all sorted units. Merge unit-level spike times per channel. Convert spike times to spike count arrays aligned to behavioral sampling frequency.

Compute frame-to-frame displacement of the target position. Detect new trial onsets when displacement exceeds a threshold (movement > 1 unit). Segment neural and behavioral data into trials based on detected change points.
Spike binning: Count spikes in non-overlapping bins of fixed length (bin_size, default 5 samples). Behavior binning: Average cursor position over the same bin windows for alignment.

Apply a sliding window (window_size, default 100 bins) with a set stride (stride, default 10 bins). For each trial, create paired (features, labels) windows: Features: [window_size, n_channels] spike count arrays. Labels: [window_size, behavior_dim] binned cursor positions.

For each recording session: spikes.npy: Shape (n_samples, window_size, n_channels) behaviors.npy: Shape (n_samples, window_size, behavior_dim) Raster plots (.png) for the first 3 trials as visualization.
dataset_root/ session_1/ spikes.npy behaviors.npy trial_0_raster.png trial_1_raster.png trial_2_raster.png session_2/ ...

To run preprocessing: python preprocess.py \ --data_root ./3854034 \ --save_root ./out \ --bin_size 5 \ --window_size 100 \ --stride 10 After running, the processed data can be loaded via: import numpy as np spikes = np.load('./out/session_1/spikes.npy') behaviors = np.load('./out/session_1/behaviors.npy')

Method: Wide-field calcium imaging was used to record fluorescent signals from the mouse cortex, while simultaneously recording behavioral activity. Subjects: 5 mice. Experimental paradigm: Neural activity and behavioral performance were recorded synchronously to analyze the relationship between cortical dynamics and behavior.

Read experimental configuration information Read the mapping between Data_ID and corresponding mouse number (Mouse_#) from data_64_5mice.csv for subsequent output file naming. Read behavioral labels (run/rest segments for each mouse) from runrest_5mice.mat. Obtain the list of .tif filenames corresponding to each mouse number, with each Data_ID representing one imaging experiment. Image loading and preprocessing Use tifffile to read .tif wide-field calcium imaging data, ensuring the data shape is [T, C, H, W] (number of time frames T, number of channels C, spatial resolution H×W). Find the label sequence that best matches the number of image frames (allowing ±5 frame tolerance) and truncate sequences that are too long. Loading mean / standard deviation Load the per-pixel mean and standard deviation matrices for each Data_ID from the precomputed _mean.npy and _std.npy files for normalization. Frame-wise normalization Perform per-pixel normalization for each frame: norm=x−meanstd+1×10−5_{\text{norm}} = \frac{x - \text{mean}}{\text{std} + 1\times 10^{-5}}norm​=std+1×10−5x−mean​ Keep the channel dimension [C, H, W]; if flatten=True, flatten each frame and take the mean across channels to obtain a [C] feature vector. Sequence windowing Set the time window length to T=30; use consecutive 30 frames as one sample, sliding to generate all possible window sequences. The label of each window is determined by majority voting among labels in the window (np.bincount().argmax()). Naming rules and saving The output file naming format is: YYYYMMDD_Mouse#.npz Inside each .npz file: calcium → windowed image features label → corresponding window labels If the file already exists, _v2, _v3, etc., will be appended to the filename to prevent overwriting. i]['Data_ID'].values filename = np.hstack([filename, files]) return filename def load_image(path): img = tifffile.imread(path) if img.ndim == 3: img = img[:, np.newaxis, :, :] return img.astype(np.float32) def get_framewise_labels(mat_entry): segments = mat_entry[0] label_seq = [seg.flatten() for seg in segments] return np.concatenate(label_seq) def find_matching_segment(mat_entry, T_img, tolerance=1): for seg in mat_entry[0]: y = seg.flatten() if abs(len(y) - T_img) <= 5: if len(y) < T_img: y = np.pad(y, (0, T_img - len(y))) else: y = y[:T_img] return y raise ValueError(f"Cannot find a label segment that matches the image frame count {T_img}.") mean_dict = {} std_dict = {} save_path = 'datasets/10408334/data/mean_and_std/' for i in df['Data_ID']: m = np.load(save_path + i + '_mean.npy') s = np.load(save_path + i + '_std.npy') mean_dict[i] = m std_dict[i] = s def _unique_path(path): if not os.path.exists(path): return path base, ext = os.path.splitext(path) k = 2 while True: cand = f"{base}_v{k}{ext}" if not os.path.exists(cand): return cand k += 1 def build_NTC_direct_and_save(mouse_nums, csv_path, root_npz_dir, T=30, flatten=True): os.makedirs(root_npz_dir, exist_ok=True) df = pd.read_csv(csv_path) id_to_mouse = dict(zip(df['Data_ID'], df['Mouse_#'])) for mouse_num in mouse_nums: for fname in get_filename([mouse_num]): print(f"{fname}.tif") X = load_image(os.path.join(image_path, fname + '.tif')) mat_entry = mat_data[f'runrest{mouse_num}'] Y = find_matching_segment(mat_entry, T_img) assert len(X) == len(Y), f"{fname}: Number of image frames {len(X)} != number of labels {len(Y)}" mean = mean_dict[fname] # [H, W] std = std_dict[fname] # [H, W] X_list, Y_list = [], [] for j in range(len(Y)): x = X[j][0] # [H, W] y = int(Y[j]) x = (x - mean) / (std + 1e-5) x = x[np.newaxis, :, :] # [C, H, W] if flatten: x = x.reshape(x.shape[0], -1).mean(axis=-1) # [C] X_list.append(x) Y_list.append(y) X_all = np.stack(X_list) # [T_img, C] or [T_img, C, H, W] Y_all = np.array(Y_list) # [T_img] del X_list, Y_list, X, Y gc.collect() if len(X_all) < T: print(f"跳过 {fname}, 帧数 {len(X_all)} < T={T}") continue N = len(X_all) - T + 1 X_windows = np.stack([X_all[i:i+T] for i in range(N)]) # [N, T, ...] Y_windows = np.array([np.bincount(Y_all[i:i+T]).argmax() for i in range(N)]) # [N] date_part = fname[:8] mouse_no = id_to_mouse.get(fname, f"M{mouse_num}") base = f"{date_part}_{mouse_no}.npz" save_path = _unique_path(os.path.join(root_npz_dir, base)) np.savez(save_path, calcium=X_windows, label=Y_windows) print(f"{os.path.basename(save_path)} | calcium {X_windows.shape}, label {Y_windows.shape}") # 调用 build_NTC_direct_and_save( mouse_nums=range(1, 6),
